title: How to Buy Milk Allergy Free Chocolate

steps.headline: Read the labels on chocolate packaging.
steps.description: The ingredients list and associated informative language will help you to work out which brands or styles of chocolate are milk-free. Look for such words as "dairy-free", "milk-free", "suitable for vegans", or similar. Equally, look for "made in a place that uses milk", "processed on the same machinery where milk is used", etc. ; if you are highly allergic to milk (meaning that you have an extremely low tolerance to milk proteins), these phrases provide an indicator to avoid that brand or type of chocolate altogether because there is a real risk of some milk protein being transferred to the chocolate during manufacturing.

steps.headline: Watch out for milk-related terms in chocolate ingredient lists (This includes filled chocolates or chocolate-flavored products).
steps.description:
Some of the more common ingredients to be concerned about include:
Whey
Milk solids (curds)
Casein, often written as sodium caseinate
Lactose, galactose (and most ingredients beginning with "lact"-)
Caramel coloring; unless indicated otherwise, this is often derived from milk.

steps.headline: Start with your local supermarket.
steps.description: Check the labels, as explained above, for all of the brands that it stocks. You never know which ones might be milk-free. If there are none, consider asking the store manager to get some milk-free chocolate in, at least on a trial basis.

steps.headline: Look for specialty stores, especially those carrying health food or vegan food supplies.
steps.description: These stores may stock dairy-free chocolate, especially if they have vegan clientele or they already cater to allergy-free customers. As well as walk-in stores, you may be able to find these stores online, either via their own websites or through an intermediary website such as an auction site. Don't forget boutique chocolate makers. Many such makers pride themselves on using the very best chocolate from some of the renowned chocolate growing areas of the world, and they are less likely to adulterate fine quality chocolate with milk. Check which manufacturers are happy to send their dairy-free chocolate products overseas to you if you don't find local stores (either real shopfronts or online stores) in your area or country. Be sure to check with customs about any charges on such foods coming in to your country.

text:
Checking the labels Read the labels on chocolate packaging. The ingredients list and associated informative language will help you to work out which brands or styles of chocolate are milk-free. Look for such words as "dairy-free", "milk-free", "suitable for vegans", or similar. Equally, look for "made in a place that uses milk", "processed on the same machinery where milk is used", etc. ; if you are highly allergic to milk (meaning that you have an extremely low tolerance to milk proteins), these phrases provide an indicator to avoid that brand or type of chocolate altogether because there is a real risk of some milk protein being transferred to the chocolate during manufacturing. Watch out for milk-related terms in chocolate ingredient lists (This includes filled chocolates or chocolate-flavored products). Some of the more common ingredients to be concerned about include:
Whey
Milk solids (curds)
Casein, often written as sodium caseinate
Lactose, galactose (and most ingredients beginning with "lact"-)
Caramel coloring; unless indicated otherwise, this is often derived from milk. Finding the milk-free chocolate Start with your local supermarket. Check the labels, as explained above, for all of the brands that it stocks. You never know which ones might be milk-free. If there are none, consider asking the store manager to get some milk-free chocolate in, at least on a trial basis. Look for specialty stores, especially those carrying health food or vegan food supplies. These stores may stock dairy-free chocolate, especially if they have vegan clientele or they already cater to allergy-free customers. As well as walk-in stores, you may be able to find these stores online, either via their own websites or through an intermediary website such as an auction site. Don't forget boutique chocolate makers. Many such makers pride themselves on using the very best chocolate from some of the renowned chocolate growing areas of the world, and they are less likely to adulterate fine quality chocolate with milk. Check which manufacturers are happy to send their dairy-free chocolate products overseas to you if you don't find local stores (either real shopfronts or online stores) in your area or country. Be sure to check with customs about any charges on such foods coming in to your country.
